data.title: Treasury Yields Fall Amid Tariffs Lull — Market Talk
data.description: Treasury yields lose steam as the trade war cools down a little and both factory orders and job openings in the U.S. fall. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal expect the ADP private-sector jobs report tomorrow to show an increase to 150,000 from December's 122,000, while December trade deficit is forecast to widen to $96.8 billion from $78.19 billion. Jobless claims on Thursday are expected to accelerate and Friday's payrolls increases are expected to slow. Analysts show increasing concerns over stickier inflation and weaker growth potentially resulting from trade wars. The 10-year yield loses 0.031 percentage point to 4.511% and the two-year falls 0.051 p.p. to 4.213%. (paulo.trevisani@wsj.com; @ptrevisani)

data.title: Dynacor Group Files Prospectus Supplement for Upsized C$27.5 Million Stock Offering
data.description:
Dynacor Group said Tuesday it filed a prospectus supplement for its offering of up to 5-million shares at $5.50 per share, for gross proceeds of up to $27.5 million.

The offering will be made through Canaccord Genuity as the sole agent, which has an option to sell up to 15% more shares than originally offered within 30 days after the closing date.

The securities will not be sold in the US, the company said, adding that the offering is subject to regulatory approvals, including from the Toronto Stock Exchange.

Dynacor plans to use the funds primarily for constructing a new pilot processing plant and expanding its business in Senegal, along with other projects in Africa and Latin America, and for working capital. The offering is set to close on or around Thursday.

The company's shares were last seen down $0.02 to $5.56 on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

data.title: Top Cryptocurrencies Fall; Bitcoin Drops Below $100,000
data.description:
Major digital assets retreated Tuesday with Bitcoin (BTC/USD) sliding below $100,000.

The CoinDesk Market Index, which tracks 124 digital assets, fell 2.6% in the past 24 hours. The Nasdaq 100 rose 1.2% in late trading, the S&P 500 climbed 0.7% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3%.

Bitcoin was 2.6% lower at $98,808, according to CoinMarketCap data. The most popular cryptocurrency's 24-hour trading volume fell 41% to $70.46 billion.

Ethereum (ETH/USD), the second-largest digital asset by market value, climbed 0.9% to $2,737.

XRP (XRP/USD) shed 3.2%, Solana (SOL/USD) lost 1.8%, and BNB (BNB/USD) tumbled 4.5%.

Dogecoin (DOGE/USD) slumped 4.8%, while Cardano (ADA/USD) lost 3.8%.

The US 10-year Treasury yield stood at 4.509% at 3 p.m. ET Tuesday, down from 4.541% Monday, while the five-year yield eased to 4.315% from 4.355%.

The total market value of the cryptocurrency industry decreased 2.8% in the past 24 hours to $3.23 trillion, while the 24-hour trading volume fell 48% to $192.91 billion.

data.title: Wheat Futures Rise on Rising Russian Prices - Daily Grain Highlights
data.description:
By Kirk Maltais

-Wheat for March delivery rose 1.9%, to $5.78 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade on Tuesday, in response to climbing domestic prices for wheat in Russia, which is expected to lift export prices.

-Soybeans for March delivery rose 1.6%, to $10.75 a bushel.

-Corn for March delivery rose 1.1%, to $4.94 1/4 a bushel.

HIGHLIGHTS

Breaking Bread: Higher prices for Russian wheat translated to support for CBOT wheat futures in Tuesday's session. Agricultural research firm SovEcon said that the average domestic price for Russian wheat has risen to 15,526 rubles, or $158 a metric ton. In U.S. dollars, that is up 9% since the start of the year, according to SovEcon. The firm says that exporters have been increasingly buying up Russian wheat in recent months, supporting the higher price.

Showing Restraint: New U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods were met with retaliation from China, which resulted in selling in CBOT soybean futures overnight. But that selling was short-lived, with soybeans and other grains turning positive through Tuesday's trading. Traders who have spoken to The Wall Street Journal say that a lot of market activity has become reactive to new headlines, but is showing restraint in light of trade uncertainty. "I think the trade is well braced for this," said Terry Reilly of Marex.

INSIGHT

Purchasing Implications: China's retaliatory tariffs made no mention of raw soybeans, but traders are wondering nonetheless about whether China will curb its purchases. "Remember, we are looking to see if there is any new commodity buying by China, versus just 'maneuvering to avoid tariffs,'" said Naomi Blohm of Total Farm Marketing in a note.

Looking on the Bright Side: U.S. farmers carried an optimistic outlook into 2025, according to the latest Ag Economy Barometer published by Purdue University and the CME Group. Surveyed farmers said that their view of current conditions of the agricultural economy have improved, buoyed by a month of gains for row crop prices on the CBOT. Farmers are increasingly expecting to have a "more robust" year financially than last year--although some concerns remain. Some 42% of surveyed farmers identified trade policy as their top policy concern over the next five years, although the share of farmers thinking that a trade war is unlikely grew in January.

Tough Times: Grain merchant ADM said, as part of its plan to cut costs, it could shutter or divest facilities that are in need of repair, have a history of poor performance or are located in areas with excess capacity. CEO Juan Luciano said on a call with investors that the company has identified about $2 billion worth of opportunities. The company is facing pressure from low crop prices and falling profit margins in its oilseed-processing business. "We will execute on this over time," Luciano said.

AHEAD

  • The EIA will release its weekly ethanol production and stocks report at 10:30 a.m. ET Wednesday.
  • Corteva will release its fourth-quarter earnings report after the market closes on Wednesday.
  • The USDA will release its weekly export sales report at 8:30 a.m. ET Thursday.
  • Patrick Thomas contributed to this article.

Write to Kirk Maltais at kirk.maltais@wsj.com

data.title: EB5 Capital Secures $100 Million Credit Facility
data.description:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 04, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) — EB5 Capital, a leading Regional Center operator in the EB-5 industry, announced today that it has secured a $100 million credit facility with EagleBank , one of the largest community banks in the Washington, DC area. This new credit facility, which doubles the firm’s previous $50 million credit line with EagleBank, will significantly enhance EB5 Capital’s ability to remove syndication risk for its sponsors and provide the necessary capital to support future growth.

“This credit facility marks a monumental step forward for EB5 Capital,” said Daniel Shiff, Chief Investment Officer & Managing Partner at EB5 Capital. “It represents our vision of building a company that not only provides valuable investment opportunities but also structures deals in ways that benefit our investors and partners.”

The expanded credit facility strengthens EB5 Capital's ability to confidently support its sponsors, ensuring access to the necessary funds to close deals and continue the momentum of its portfolio, which now includes over 40 U.S.-based commercial real estate projects. This increased capacity will provide EB5 Capital with greater flexibility in deal structuring, enabling the company to continue attracting high-quality investors and advancing transformative real estate developments that generate jobs and drive economic growth nationwide.

“When we started with just a handful of people over 15 years ago, we could not have imagined the journey we would be on,” said Joseph Tilley, Chief Financial Officer at EB5 Capital. “To now qualify for a $100 million credit line from a leading bank like EagleBank is truly remarkable. It speaks volumes about the strength of our team and our continued growth as a company.”

“EagleBank is proud to support our partners at EB5 Capital in their mission to drive job creation,” stated Evelyn Lee, EVP, Chief Lending Officer C&I at EagleBank. “We look forward to continuing to build our organization into the best community bank for commercial businesses.”

EB5 Capital’s prior $50 million credit facility played a pivotal role in the successful execution of recent investments, and the company is poised to capture even more opportunities with this expanded credit line.

About EB5 Capital

EB5 Capital provides qualified foreign investors with opportunities to invest in job-creating commercial real estate projects under the United States Immigrant Investor Program (EB-5 Visa Program). Headquartered in Washington, DC, EB5 Capital’s distinguished track record and leadership in the industry has attracted investors from over 75 countries. As one of the oldest and most active Regional Center operators in the country, the firm has raised over $1 billion of foreign capital across approximately 40 EB-5 projects. 100% of our investors’ funds are protected by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) insurance prior to their deployment into our projects. Please visit www.eb5capital.com for more information.  

About Eagle Bancorp, Inc. and EagleBank

Eagle Bancorp, Inc. is the holding company for EagleBank, which commenced operations in 1998. EagleBank is headquartered in Bethesda, Maryland, and conducts full service commercial banking through 12 offices, located in Suburban, Maryland, Washington, D.C. and Northern Virginia. EagleBank focuses on building relationships with businesses, professionals and individuals in its marketplace.

Contact:

Katherine Willis

Director, Marketing & Communications

media@eb5capital.com

data.title: Riverview Bancorp Reports Third Fiscal Quarter 2025 Results
data.description:
Riverview Bancorp, Inc., headquartered in Vancouver, WA, has released its financial results for the third fiscal quarter ending December 31, 2024. The company reported a net income of $1.2 million, or $0.06 per diluted share, reflecting a decrease from the previous quarter's $1.6 million, or $0.07 per diluted share.

Financial Highlights

For the third fiscal quarter of 2025, Riverview Bancorp reported:

  • Net interest income increased to $9.4 million, up from $8.9 million in the preceding quarter.
  • Net interest margin (NIM) improved to 2.60%, a 14 basis point increase from the previous quarter.
  • Total loans were $1.05 billion, slightly down from $1.06 billion in the previous quarter.
  • Total deposits were $1.22 billion, consistent with the same period last year.
  • Tangible book value per share was $6.20, down from $6.33 in the previous quarter.

Business and Operational Highlights

Riverview Trust Company, a subsidiary of Riverview Bancorp, saw its assets under management increase to $872.6 million. Asset management fees also improved, reaching $1.4 million for the quarter. The company maintained strong asset quality, with non-performing assets at $469,000, or 0.03% of total assets.

Strategic Initiatives and Corporate Developments

During the third quarter, Riverview Bancorp repurchased 200,073 shares of common stock at an average price of $5.43 under its stock repurchase program. The company also paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.02 per share on January 14, 2025.

Management's Perspective

Nicole Sherman, President and CEO, highlighted the company's steady improvements in net interest margin due to stabilizing funding costs and higher loan yields. CFO David Lam noted the positive impact of recent Federal Reserve rate reductions on deposit costs and interest expenses. COO Dan Cox emphasized the company's focus on managing the balance sheet and improving performance metrics.

Future Outlook

Riverview Bancorp anticipates further stabilization of deposit costs in future quarters, driven by recent Federal Reserve rate cuts. The company also expects continued improvements in loan yields and asset management fees.

SEC Filing: RIVERVIEW BANCORP INC [ RVSB ] - 8-K - Feb. 04, 2025

data.title: ICE canola futures rise on tariffs suspension relief
data.description:
ICE canola futures rose Tuesday and were stronger than most vegoils, as relief about tariffs continued to calm the market.

• March canola (RSH5) settled up $6.70 at $647.20 per metric ton, a second day of gains.

• Traders said U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to suspend his threat of 25% tariffs on Canadian products is a relief for people worried about exposure to volatile politics.

* Trump's threat is only lifted for 30 days from Monday, but traders have at least some breathing room and "we'll have to see how the next month goes," said a trader. Canadian canola seed, oil and meal all have major markets in the U.S.

* Canadian canola futures had weakened over fears that demand for canola oil would lose demand from U.S. biodiesel producers if tariffs were applied.

• Chicago Board of Trade soyoil futures (BOv1) fell 1.61% on likelihood of more competition from Canadian canola oil. Soybeans rose on relief that trade disputes are now less likely to affect exports, now that Mexico and Canada have a 30-day reprieve.

• Euronext rapeseed futures (COMc1) rose 0.58% and Malaysian palm oil futures fell 1.35%.

• The Canadian dollar hit a 13 day high while the U.S. dollar fell on tariff-suspension relief.

data.title: Bitcoin block size could grow to 4 MB with inscriptions: Research
data.description:
Widespread adoption of inscriptions could drive the Bitcoin network’s average block size as high as 4 megabytes (MB) per block, far higher than current averages, according to a Feb. 4 report by Mempool Research. 

Bitcoin’s average block size — the amount of data contained in each block posted to the network’s public ledger — is currently slightly above 1.5 MB, according to the report. 

Bitcoin’s block size could increase significantly if inscriptions, a method for efficiently encoding arbitrary data inside a block, are more widely adopted, Mempool Research said. 

Block size is among the most significant constraints on the Bitcoin network’s scalability. By comparison, rival blockchain Solana can theoretically store up to 128 MB per block, according to the Solana Foundation. 

Following the network’s 2021 Taproot upgrade, some Bitcoin blocks have stored as much as 2.4 MB of data, according to the report. Each Bitcoin block could potentially contain as much as 4 MB, it added. 

“We project a range of potential growth scenarios for the Bitcoin blockchain, spanning from a return to pre-inscription dynamics (yielding slower growth) to widespread inscription adoption (potentially driving growth as high as 4 MB per block),” the report said.

“Under these scenarios, the blockchain could reach 1 TB as early as late 2026, though mid 2027-2029 seems more likely,” it added. 

Growing pains

Bitcoin (BTC) originated as a simple peer-to-peer payment protocol, but its 2021 Taproot upgrade enabled the network to support more complex activities, including creating and trading other types of tokens and minting non-fungible tokens (NFTs). 

Since then, Bitcoin’s emerging ecosystem of native decentralized exchanges and layer-2 scaling solutions has reinvigorated the oldest blockchain network.

Bitcoin-native decentralized finance (DeFi) is expected to be among the hottest themes in 2025 as institutional Bitcoin adoption accelerates and its DeFi ecosystem matures, several industry executives told Cointelegraph. 

However, Bitcoin faces competition from networks touting far more block space, enabling more complex transactions and potentially lower costs for users. 

In September, Celestia — a layer-1 network specializing in data availability — unveiled a technical roadmap charting a path to scaling block size to 1 gigabyte.

data.title: 30-Year Treasury Yield Falls to 4.747% — Data Talk
data.description:
The 30-year yield declined 0.024 percentage point to 4.747% today. The price rose 12/32 to 96 3/32.

  • Yield is down for two consecutive trading days
  • Yield is down 0.065 percentage point over the last two trading days
  • Largest two-day yield decline since Monday, Jan. 27, 2025
  • Yield is down three of the past four trading days
  • Lowest yield since Friday, Dec. 20, 2024
  • Yield is off 0.239 percentage point from its 52-week high of 4.986% hit Monday, Jan. 13, 2025
  • Yield is up 0.811 percentage point from its 52-week low of 3.936% hit Monday, Sept. 16, 2024
  • Yield is up 0.451 percentage point from 52 weeks ago
  • Year-to-date the yield is down 0.039 percentage point

Data based on 3 p.m. ET values

Source: Tradeweb FTSE U.S. Treasury Closing Prices

data.title: 2-Year Treasury Yield Falls to 4.213% — Data Talk
data.description:
The 2-year yield declined 0.051 percentage point to 4.213% today. The price rose 3/32 to 99 27/32.

  • Largest one-day yield decline since Monday, Jan. 27, 2025
  • Snaps a two-trading-day streak of rising yields
  • Today's yield is the fourth lowest this year
  • Yield is off 0.830 percentage point from its 52-week high of 5.043% hit Tuesday, April 30, 2024
  • Yield is up 0.664 percentage point from its 52-week low of 3.549% hit Tuesday, Sept. 24, 2024
  • Yield is down 0.193 percentage point from 52 weeks ago
  • Yield is off 0.187 percentage point from its 2025 closing high of 4.399

% hit Monday, Jan. 13, 2025

data.title: Equity Markets Higher Ahead of Alphabet Earnings
data.description:
US benchmark equity indexes were higher ahead of Tuesday's close, shrugging off trade concerns after China announced a series of retaliatory tariffs against the US.

The Nasdaq Composite was up 1.2% at 19,631.9, while the S&P 500 rose 0.7% to 6,036.8. The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.3% to 44,553.8. Among sectors, energy paced the gainers, while utilities saw the biggest drop.

China will impose additional tariffs of 15% on coal and liquefied natural gas imports from the US and 10% higher duties on items including American crude oil and agricultural machinery, effective Feb. 10, China's finance ministry said Tuesday.

Google parent Alphabet is scheduled to report results after the closing bell, along with other companies including Advanced Micro Devices , Amgen and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).

The US two-year yield was down 5.3 basis points at 4.21%, while the 10-year rate dropped three basis points to 4.51%.

West Texas Intermediate crude oil was down 0.9% at $72.5 a barrel.

data.title: Apollo Eyes 'Industrial Renaissance' After Investing Record $222 Billion Last Year - Update
data.description:
By Luis Garcia and Rob Curran

Apollo Global Management invested a firm record of $222 billion last year as the credit specialist sees increased opportunities to finance infrastructure developers in what it calls a "global industrial renaissance."

"We are quite focused on increasing our capacity to originate" new investments, Chief Executive Marc Rowan said Tuesday during a call with analysts to discuss the New York-based firm's results during last year's fourth quarter. "That's what we intend to do."

Rowan was referring partly to Apollo's agreed-to acquisition of Argo Infrastructure Partners, a fund manager with about $6 billion in assets across industries such as digital infrastructure, renewable energy and transportation. The deal, unveiled last month, is part of Apollo's effort to expand its investments in assets and businesses across various fast-growing industries.

"This is not just about [artificial intelligence] and DeepSeek," Rowan said. "This is about fundamental investments in energy, in infrastructure, in power, in data, in next-generation manufacturing and a host of other things that are going to be needed [and] financed."

Rowan added that projects in those industries are typically "long dated and complex," making them less suitable for traditional bank financing and creating opportunities for private-credit firms.

Apollo's record origination, a metric that reflects new investments, last year was more than double the $97 billion invested in 2023, according to a presentation of the results. Apollo originated $61 billion during last year's fourth quarter alone, its second highest quarterly total to date, according to Rowan.

The firm's funds brought in $152 billion in fresh capital last year, slightly less than $157 billion in 2023. That helped lift its total assets under management by about 15%, to $751 billion at the end of December, $616 billion of which in credit strategies, the presentation showed.

Apollo's asset management business accounted for about $81 billion of last year's capital inflows, while the firm's insurer Athene represented $71 billion, James Zelter, Apollo's president, said during Tuesday's earnings call.

"In short, both sides of the house produced." Zelter said. "Alongside origination, capital formation is the lifeblood of our continued growth."

Apollo recently promoted Zelter to president of the holding company that also includes Athene, while former head of credit John Zito took his place as co-president of the firm's asset-management arm alongside Scott Kleinman. The promotions have been seen as an effort to clarify possible successors to Rowan.

Apollo plans to expand its investments across strategies such as asset-backed financing and direct lending, including to large businesses whose capital needs are too

big to be met in public-debt markets alone, Zelter said. As examples, he cited the joint venture that Apollo formed last year with chip maker Intel, which involved an $11 billion investment, and the $700 million financing it led for music company Sony Music Group.

Zelter added that Apollo is also looking to back companies that private-equity firms are having difficulty selling or otherwise exiting through an initial public offering.

"When you think about the overhang from PE sponsors, when you think about the other challenges right now in monetization of the IPO market, certainly I think you're going to see a much, much greater volume of opportunity in the U.S. and in Europe and parts of Asia," he said.

Apollo posted earnings of $1.49 billion, or $2.39 a share, down from $2.76 billion, or $4.44 a share, a year earlier.

On an adjusted basis, Apollo posted earnings of $1.36 billion, or $2.22 a share, a quarterly record, beating the average analyst peg of $1.85 a share, as per FactSet.

Apollo declared a dividend of 46.25 cents a per share, payable Feb. 28 to holders of record at the close of business on Feb. 18.

Write to Luis Garcia at luis.garcia@wsj.com and Rob Curran at rob.curran@wsj.com

data.title: Canada Economics Brief: President Trump During Brief In Oval Office Cites Tariffs Pause With Canada and Mexico, and Their Agreement To Strengthen Borders With US
Canada Economics Brief: President Trump Says "We'll See What Happens" With Tariffs
December Job Openings Slide More Than Expected
data.description:
US job openings fell more than the market projected in December as quits edged higher, government data showed Tuesday.

Vacancies declined to 7.6 million as of the last day of December from November's upwardly revised 8.16 million print, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics' job openings and labor turnover survey. The consensus was for an 8 million level in a survey compiled by Bloomberg.

Total private job openings decreased to 6.72 million in December from 7.27 million the month prior, according to BLS data. Vacancies were down by 225,000 in professional and business services and by 180,000 in health care and social assistance. They rose by 65,000 in arts, entertainment, and recreation, the BLS said.

Hires edged up to 5.46 million from 5.37 million in November, which was revised up by 104,000.

Job separations, which include quits and layoffs, moved up to 5.27 million in December from 5.23 million in November, according to the JOLTS report. Quits ticked up to 3.2 million from 3.13 million month to month while layoffs and discharges dipped to 1.77 million from 1.8 million.

"The JOLTS data painted a familiar picture of the labor market, with a low pace of layoffs keeping net job growth positive despite a slow pace of hiring," Nancy Vanden Houten, Oxford Economics' lead US economist, said in emailed remarks.

Oxford removed a March rate cut from its February baseline forecast, saying the JOLTS survey supports the Federal Reserve's view that the labor market is "healthy enough to tolerate a more cautious approach to lowering rates," particularly amid the uncertainty around tariffs, according to Vanden Houten. Last week, the Fed's monetary policy committee voted to keep interest rates unchanged following a three-meeting cut streak.

On Friday, the BLS is expected to report that the US economy added 154,000 nonfarm jobs in January, down from December's 256,000 gain.

data.title: Trump Media Partners With Moov. It's an Odd Pairing on the DEI Front. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Mackenzie Tatananni

Trump Media and Technology Group's decision to use Moov Financial to handle its payment-processing services marks the start of an unlikely partnership.

Moov is "committed to building a team that represents a variety of backgrounds, perspectives, and skills and we embrace diversity, creativity, and equal opportunity," according to a job posting dated Feb. 1. Those values are seemingly at odds with those of Trump Media's majority shareholder, President Donald Trump, who has made quashing diversity, equity, and inclusion an objective of his administration.

Neither Moov nor Trump Media immediately responded to requests for comment. In a statement Monday, Moov CEO Wade Arnold praised Trump Media for "building a dynamic platform for free expression."

On Monday, Trump Media said it had signed an agreement with Moov to handle payment processing for its Truth Social platform and video streaming service Truth+. The company's Truth. Fi fintech services brand, which is expected to roll out later this year, will also use Moov's secure payment processing, Trump Media said.

Moov, founded in 2017 as an open-source fintech platform, is also the organizer of fintech_devcon, an annual developer conference. In 2021, Moov unveiled a "diversity scholarship" that would allow recipients from "underrepresented communities" to attend the first of those conferences.

According to a profile on Built In, a tech-oriented job board, Moov boasts a "dedicated diversity and inclusion staff" as well as an equal-pay policy and required unconscious-bias training. The same profile mentions "hiring practices that promote diversity," including partnerships with "diversity-focused communities and recruiting platforms."

All that contrasts with actions taken by Trump, the majority owner of Trump Media Group, since he was sworn into office on Jan. 20.

On Jan. 22, Trump signed an executive order directing federal agencies to "end illegal DEI" and terminate so-called DEI discrimination in the federal workforce. The mandate revoked Executive Order 11246, which was signed by President Lyndon Johnson in 1965 to establish requirements for nondiscriminatory hiring practices for government contractors.

In an order issued Jan. 27, Trump eliminated DEI offices and policies within the Department of Defense and Department of Homeland Security, claiming "the Armed Forces have been afflicted with radical gender ideology."

The president also appeared to blame diversity initiatives at the Federal Aviation Administration for the midair collision that killed 67 people in Washington, D.C., last week. During a press conference on Jan. 30, Trump claimed, without evidence, that the Biden administration allowed people with intellectual and psychiatric impairments to work for the FAA.

Trump appeared to walk back his remarks later that day, saying DEI "may have" contributed to the crash. But the White House released a memo doubling down on claims that the Biden administration "egregiously rejected merit-based hiring," which led to the FAA recruiting people with "severe intellectual disabilities."

Truth Social positioned itself as an alternative to Twitter and Facebook when it launched in 2022. The platform says it provides a safe harbor from censorship by large tech corporations and that it is free of political discrimination.

Write to Mackenzie Tatananni at mackenzie.tatananni@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Michigan School District to Sell $81.3M in Bonds for School Projects
data.description:
By Paulo Trevisani

Michigan's Traverse City Area Public Schools plans to issue $81.3 million in municipal bonds to finance school improvements and new facility construction.

Proceeds from the 2025 School Building and Site Bonds (General Obligation - Unlimited Tax) will be used for building renovations, new school facilities, technology upgrades, bus purchases, and improvements to athletic fields and playgrounds, according to a document posted Monday on MuniOS.

The school district includes the entire city of Traverse and all or part of 13 townships in Grand Traverse, Leelanau and Benzie counties.

The bonds will be repaid through local taxes. They have been assigned an AA- rating by S&P Global Ratings.

Maturities range from 2026 to 2035. The maximum interest rate is 5.5%, with the purchase price set between 100% and 120% of par value.

PFM Financial Advisors is the municipal advisor for the deal. The sale is scheduled for Feb. 12.

The bonds aren't subject to early redemption.

Write to Paulo Trevisani at paulo.trevisani@wsj.com

data.title: Sector Update: Health Care Stocks Decline Late Afternoon
data.description:
Health care stocks fell late Tuesday afternoon with the NYSE Health Care Index down 0.4% and the Health Care Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLV) shedding 0.3%.

The iShares Biotechnology ETF (IBB) rose 0.5%.

In corporate news, Quantum BioPharma shares more than doubled. The company said a trial of its dietary supplement Unbuzzd confirmed it accelerates alcohol metabolism, speeds the reduction of blood alcohol concentration and reduces symptoms of intoxication, impairment and hangover.

Turnstone Biologics decided to discontinue all clinical trials assessing Tidal-01 in solid tumors and launched a process to explore alternatives to maximize shareholder value. The stock jumped 10%.

Merck issued a downbeat full-year outlook, overshadowing stronger-than-expected Q4 results. The shares fell 9.2%.

Pfizer's Q4 results topped market expectations amid double-digit revenue growth across key segments, while the pharmaceutical giant reiterated its full-year outlook. The shares dropped 1.2%.

data.title: BTC volatility hits record low, stablecoin transaction value tops Visa — ARK
data.description:
2024 was a watershed year for digital assets, with Bitcoin’s annual volatility reaching a record low and stablecoin transaction values exceeding Visa and Mastercard.

These are among the major takeaways from ARK Invest’s “Big Ideas 2025” report, released on Feb. 4. According to the report, Bitcoin’s annualized one-year volatility fell below 50% in 2024. By comparison, BTC volatility was closer to 80% in 2022 and well above 100% in 2018.

A large part of Bitcoin’s success in 2024 was owed to the “most successful ETF launch in history,” ARK said, referring to the 11 spot exchange-traded funds that were approved in the US in January. 

By the end of the year, the US spot Bitcoin ETFs had accumulated more than $100 billion in net assets. 

At the same time, Bitcoin’s inflation rate fell to 0.9% after the quadrennial halving in April, marking the first time in history that Bitcoin’s issuance rate was below gold’s long-term supply growth. 

Cointelegraph
@Cointelegraph

🔥 BULLISH: Ark Invest CEO Cathie Wood says, “The more uncertainty and volatility there is in the global economies, the more our confidence increases in #Bitcoin.” pic.twitter.com/siX3HEfWYo

Jan 05, 2025

Stablecoins: Crypto’s other major use case 

In addition to Bitcoin, stablecoins cemented themselves as a dominant blockchain use case in 2024, with annualized transaction value reaching $15.6 trillion, which is roughly 119% and 200% of Visa’s and Mastercard’s, respectively. 

“The number of transactions hit 110 million monthly, roughly 0.41% and 0.72% of those processed by Visa and Mastercard, respectively,” the report said. However, “the stablecoin value per transaction is much higher than that for Visa and Mastercard.”

On the regulatory front, stablecoins are a top priority for pro-crypto Republicans in Congress. Before the November presidential election, Senator Bill Hagerty introduced the Clarity for Payment Stablecoins Act of 2024, which builds off a previous proposal by former House member Patrick McHenry. 

Earlier in the year, Democratic Senator Kirsten Gillibrand and Republican counterpart Cynthia Lummis introduced a bipartisan bill to establish a regulatory framework for stablecoins. 

After Republicans swept both houses of Congress during the November elections, “passing comprehensive market structure and stablecoin legislation” is an important first step for cementing clear crypto guidelines, according to Republican Representative Tom Emmer.

Miller Whitehouse-Levine, who heads the DeFi Education Fund advocacy group, told Bloomberg that stablecoin regulation has reached a “broad consensus” in Congress.

data.title: Otter Tail Raises Quarterly Dividend by 12.3% to $0.525 per Share, Payable March 10 to Holders of Record on Feb. 14
Sector Update: Consumer Stocks Mixed in Late Afternoon Trading
data.description:
Consumer stocks were mixed late Tuesday afternoon with the Consumer Staples Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLP) shedding 0.8% and the Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLY) rising 1%.

Redbook US same-store sales last week rose 5.7% from a year earlier after a 4.9% increase in the previous week.

In corporate news, Lottery.com shares surged 72% after the company said it was launching international lottery operations to generate additional revenue.

Getty Images said Tuesday that it expects Q4 revenue in the range of $244 million to $250 million, compared with $225.9 million a year earlier. Analysts polled by FactSet expect $245.5 million. Its shares added 1.4%.

Estee Lauder shares fell past 16% after it reported lower fiscal Q2 results. The company expects to eliminate 5,800 to 7,000 job roles as part of a restructuring plan.

PepsiCo's Q4 earnings topped Wall Street's estimates, while revenue posted a surprise decline amid weakness in the beverage and snacks company's North American businesses. The stock dropped 4.3%.

data.title: How U.S. Agriculture Market Is Approaching Tariffs and Potential Trade War — Analysis
data.description:
By Kirk Maltais

U.S. agriculture is attempting to maintain optimism in the face of President Donald Trump's threats of tariffs on its major customers - Canada, Mexico, and China.

While a 10% tariff on Chinese goods did go into effect Tuesday - and was met by targeted retaliatory tariffs on some U.S. goods - delays to President Trump's 25% tariffs on Canadian and Mexican goods were seen as a sign of Washington's willingness to negotiate, and the potential for agriculture to sidestep any negative impact to a farm economy that saw declining incomes last year.

Grain and livestock prices recovered from initial losses on Monday when Trump confirmed that the U.S. and Mexico had agreed to a 30-day pause in any tariff action - with a similar pause between the U.S. and Canada following later in the day. Traders and farmers hope that the administration is using tariff threats as leverage in trade negotiations, as opposed to following through with a major disruption to agricultural trade.

"I think after last time, people learned their lesson," said Terry Reilly, head grains and oilseeds analyst with Marex in Chicago. "I think the trade is well braced for this."

Grain futures trading in Chicago settled higher Tuesday, continuing the positive momentum that grain futures have all had since the start of the year, with corn rising 8%, soybeans up 6%, and wheat up 5% since Jan. 1.

The trade war between the U.S. and China that raged during Trump's first term cut into U.S. exports, particularly for soybeans - with export sales of U.S. soybeans to top buyer China falling by over 60% from 2017 to 2019, according to data from the Department of Agriculture.

There were many stops and starts in the negotiations leading to a partial trade deal between the two nations in late 2019, which called for increased purchasing of U.S. exports by China.

This time, traders and analysts appear ready for the potential chaos that may ensue in negotiations between both sides. Grain traders are moving carefully in recent sessions, limiting the amount of fluctuation seen in futures prices.

"It appears that the trade is reluctant to price in a tariff premium or discount given the speed of developments," said Jake Hanley, managing director and senior portfolio specialist with Burlington, Vt.-based Teucrium Trading LLC.

The fluid nature of the news coming out of the White House has traders glued to news coverage and Trump's Truth Social account, where he provided confirmation about Mexican and Canadian tariffs being delayed.

In the case of China, retaliatory tariffs didn't target U.S. agriculture, outside of agricultural equipment coming out of the country. The measure focused on other mostly energy commodities, including oil, gas and coal.

Farmers nationwide have become more positive about their chances to have a profitable year in 2025 and that a trade war can be avoided. In a survey conducted jointly by Purdue University and the CME Group and released this month, a growing percentage of farmers say that they don't believe a new trade war is coming - with 29% of the population calling it 'unlikely' or 'very unlikely', up 8 points from the previous month.

Meanwhile, 40% see a potential trade war as 'likely' or 'very likely', but that's down 8 points from the previous month.

"Recent improvements in crop and livestock prices have provided a boost to farmers' current sentiment," said Michael Langemeier, the principal investigator for the barometer and a professor at Purdue's school for Commercial Agriculture, in the release.

Write to Kirk Maltais at kirk.maltais@wsj.com

data.title: Eunhong (Edward) Min Named StarKist President & CEO
data.description:
(20:35 GMT) *Eunhong (Edward) Min Named StarKist President and CEO
(20:36 GMT) Press Release: Eunhong (Edward) Min Named StarKist President & CEO

Eunhong (Edward) Min Named StarKist President & CEO

PR Newswire

RESTON, Va., Feb. 4, 2025

RESTON, Va., Feb. 4, 2025 /PRNewswire/ — StarKist Co. today announced the appointment of Eunhong (Edward) Min as its new President & CEO. Min brings extensive global leadership experience and a proven track record of driving growth, operational excellence, and innovation.

"It is an honor and a profound responsibility to lead StarKist into the future," said Edward Min, President & CEO of StarKist Co. "With a strong legacy of trust, quality, and innovation, StarKist has built an unparalleled connection with consumers. As we navigate an evolving market, we will remain focused on delivering high-quality protein products that consumers love while driving strategic growth. I look forward to working with the talented StarKist team to build on this legacy and shape the future of the industry."

Before joining StarKist, Min served as CEO of Dongwon Industries since December 2022, where he led transformative initiatives integrating science and technology into the maritime industry. Prior to that, he held executive leadership roles as Executive Vice President at both Dongwon Industries and Dongwon Systems.

Min's career also includes nearly 30 years at Procter & Gamble, where he held key leadership positions across Asia. As Senior Sales Director and Commercial Leader for core Asian markets based in Singapore, he played a pivotal role in developing customer-centric strategies and driving double-digit business growth.

He holds a business degree from Yonsei University and completed the Advanced Management Program at Seoul National University.

As a socially responsible company, StarKist remains committed to providing high-quality protein products to consumers. The company looks forward to a seamless transition under Min's leadership and continued innovation in the food industry.

About StarKist Co.

StarKist Co. is a socially responsible company that empowers people to live a healthy lifestyle by providing convenient nutritious proteins. An industry innovator, StarKist was the first brand to introduce convenient single-serve pouch products, which include StarKist Tuna Creations(R) , Salmon Creations(R) , Chicken Creations(R) , and new Beef Creations(R) in over 30 flavors. As America's favorite tuna, StarKist represents a tradition of quality, consumer trust and a commitment to sustainability. StarKist's charismatic brand icon, Charlie(R) the Tuna, swam into the hearts of tuna fans in 1961 and is still a fan favorite today. StarKist Co. is a direct wholly owned subsidiary of Dongwon Industries Co., Ltd.

Press Contact:

Michelle Faist

Michelle.Faist@StarKist.com

571-441-8096

Tori Schettino

Tschettino@coynepr.com

973-588-2381

View original content to download multimedia:https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/eunhong-edward-min-named-starkist-president--ceo-302368030.html

SOURCE StarKist Co.

data.title: Oil Prices Drop as China Retaliates Against US Tariffs
data.description:
Oil prices fell intraday Tuesday after China announced various retaliatory measures against the US, including 10% higher duties on American crude oil.

Beijing will also impose an additional 10% tariffs on agricultural machinery and certain vehicles imported from the US, as well as 15% tariffs on coal and liquefied natural gas, China's ministry of finance said Tuesday. The tariffs will go into effect Feb. 10.

On Saturday, The White House said US President Donald Trump would impose 25% tariffs on goods from both Canada and Mexico, along with a 10% levy on imports from China. On Monday, he agreed to a 30-day pause on the implementation of the planned tariffs on Canada and Mexico.

WTI crude futures were down 0.9% at $72.48 a barrel in Tuesday late-afternoon trade, while Brent fell 0.2% to $75.15.

"The trade dispute between the US and China has raised demand concerns — not least in China, an economy that has grown increasingly dependent on exports at a time of weak consumer confidence at home," Saxo Bank Head of Commodity Strategy Ole Hansen said in a report published Tuesday.

The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies are on track to gradually restore output in monthly stages from April unless tariffs and sanctions "significantly" change the global demand outlook, Hansen said.

Trump was scheduled to speak with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Tuesday, the US president's top trade adviser, Peter Navarro, told a Politico Live event, Reuters reported.

data.title: What a run for gold to start the year
data.description:
Gold is posting another strong day in what's been a nearly non-stop rally to start the year. It's up $27 to a new record at $2841.

All the trade uncertainty has been a big tailwind for gold, which started the year at $2621. That's an 8% rally barely a month into the year following strong gains in 2024.

gold daily

We're getting close to the point where $3000 begins to act as a magnate but we're also getting close to the end of the early-year seasonal tailwind.

The real trigger for gold from here would be anything that weakens the US dollar. It's incredible that this bull market for gold has unfolded entirely during a bull market for the US dollar.

data.title: The bond market is signaling two things about Trump's second term
data.description:
By Joy Wiltermuth

It still pays to stick with shorter-term bonds, but concerns about growth are back

President Trump's trade-war tactics have been tough for investors to parse, especially as stocks zigzagged to start the week amid mixed message from the bond market.

Shorter 2-year Treasurys yields BX:TMUBMUSD02Y on Tuesday were near 4.21%, only slightly below their 200-day moving average, according to FactSet data. Longer 10-year yields BX:TMUBMUSD10Ywere closer to 4.51%, far above their average for the same time frame.

Tracking yields over longer stretches can help establish trends. The curious thing, however, is that both of these yields remain comfortably above levels from late August, when Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said the time had come for rate cuts.

It also comes despite warnings from Wall Street last year that investors should lock in yields before rate cuts ruin the opportunity. But the Fed already has cut its short-term policy rate by 1 percentage point since September.

"There are two narratives the bond market is wrestling with," said Lawrence Gillum, chief income strategist at LPL Research, in a phone interview Tuesday.

Yields on Treasurys that mature in two years or less reflect concerns about potential price increases and the Federal Reserve's careful approach to rate cuts, Gillum said.

Yet another recent theme relates to tariffs, and how they tend to increase prices, but also slow economic growth. Gillum expects Trump's tariffs to apply downward pressure on 10-year yields, bringing them down to the low 4% range in the back-end of the year, as investors react to growth concerns.

See: The tariff wars aren't over. China hits back over new 10% tariffs.

How should investors be positioned now? The biggest "bang for your buck," on a yield per duration basis for the Bloomberg Corporate Index, would be to keep exposure in bonds short, according to Gillum.

The chart looks at different bond maturity buckets from the corporate index, helping to measure the sensitivity a bond portfolio may have to rate changes over time.

"Right now the economy is in good shape, but it probably [won't be] toward the end of the year," Gillum told MarketWatch. "If you are managing a fixed-income portfolio relative to an industry index, and trying to outperform, our advice is stay neutral. Don't take a lot of rate risk, until we see the economic data soften."

Meanwhile, "there's a lot of value in the front-end," Gillum said, adding that it's still possible to collect around 4.5% on shorter-duration bonds, higher than seen much of the past decade.

Trump's start-stop strategy on tariffs adds other risks for investors to consider. BofA analysts estimate that the S&P 500 index SPX could see as much of an 8% hit to earnings per share from 25% tariffs on Mexico and China and 10% incremental tariffs on China.

See: As Trump's tariffs grip markets, a key indicator flashes a warning for bullish investors

Concerns about stocks stumbling from near record highs would bolster the case for owning bonds in a portfolio, but investors also don't want to wait for potentially drastic Fed rate cuts and a faltering economy to add duration.

"The big takeaway," according to Gillum, is that "volatility in fixed-income isn't going to go away."

The S&P 500 was up 0.8% on Tuesday, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA was 0.4% higher and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP was up 1.2%, according to FactSet.

Related: Stock-market investors are getting nervous about this bond-market move that's only happened twice in over 40 years

-Joy Wiltermuth

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.
